title: Lc-ms dataset template schema
description: Lc-ms dataset template schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.7.1

propertyDescriptions.lab_id: A locally assigned identifier provided by the data provider for the dataset. It is used to reference an external metadata record that may be maintained independently, enabling traceability and supporting provenance tracking. Example: Visium_9OLC_A4_S1.
propertyDescriptions.dataset_type: The specific type of dataset being produced. Default: LC-MS.
propertyDescriptions.analyte_class: The analyte class which is the target molecule that the assay is measuring. Example: Peptide.
propertyDescriptions.acquisition_instrument_vendor: The company that manufactures or supplies the acquisition instrument. An acquisition instrument is a device equipped with signal detection hardware and signal processing software. It captures signals produced by assays, such as variations in light intensity or color, or signals corresponding to molecular mass. If the instrument was custom-built or developed internally, enter "In-House". Example: Bruker.
propertyDescriptions.acquisition_instrument_model: The specific model of the acquisition instrument, as manufacturers often offer various versions with differing features or sensitivities. These differences may be relevant to the processing or interpretation of the data. If the instrument was custom-built or developed internally, enter "In-House". If the model is unknown, enter "Unknown". Example: timsTOF FleX.
propertyDescriptions.source_storage_duration_value: The length of time the sample was stored prior to processing it. For assays performed on tissue sections, this refers to how long the tissue section (e.g., slide) was stored before the assay began (e.g., imaging). For assays performed on suspensions, such as sequencing, it refers to how long the suspension was stored before library construction started. Example: 12.
propertyDescriptions.source_storage_duration_unit: The unit of measurement used to specify the source storage duration value. Example: hour.
propertyDescriptions.time_since_acquisition_instrument_calibr: The length of time since the acquisition instrument was last serviced or calibrated. This provides a metric for assessing drift in data capture. Example: 10.
The unit of measurement used to specify the time since acquisition instrument calibration value. Example: month.
propertyDescriptions.preparation_protocol_doi: The DOI for the protocols.io page that details the assay or the procedures used for sample procurement and preparation. For example, in the case of an imaging assay, the protocol may start with tissue section staining and end with the generation of an OME-TIFF file. The documented protocol should also include any image processing steps involved in producing the final OME-TIFF. Example: https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.eq2lyno9qvx9/v1.
propertyDescriptions.is_targeted: The company that manufactures or supplies the acquisition instrument. An acquisition instrument is a device equipped with signal detection hardware and signal processing software. It captures signals produced by assays, such as variations in light intensity or color, or signals corresponding to molecular mass. If the instrument was custom-built or developed internally, enter "In-House". Example: Illumina.
propertyDescriptions.contributors_path: The path to the file with the ORCID IDs for all contributors of this dataset.
propertyDescriptions.mass_analysis_polarity: The polarity mode used in mass analysis, indicating whether positive or negative ion modes are employed. Example: Positive ion mode.
propertyDescriptions.mass_to_charge_range_low_value: The low value of the scanned mass-to-charge range for MS1. This value is unitless. Example: 100.
propertyDescriptions.mass_to_charge_range_high_value: The high value of the scanned mass-to-charge range for MS1. This value is unitless. Example: 350.
propertyDescriptions.mass_resolving_power: The mass resolving power, denoted as m/∆m, where ∆m is defined as the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) for a given peak with a specified mass-to-charge ratio (m/z). This measurement is unitless. Example: 60000.
propertyDescriptions.mass_to_charge_resolving_power: The peak mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) used to calculate the resolving power. Example: 400.2.
propertyDescriptions.ion_mobility: The specific technology employed for ion mobility spectrometry. Available technologies include Traveling Wave Ion Mobility Spectrometry (TWIMS), Trapped Ion Mobility Spectrometry (TIMS), High Field Asymmetric Waveform Ion Mobility Spectrometry (FAIMS), Drift Tube Ion Mobility Spectrometry (DTIMS), Structures for Lossless Ion Manipulations (SLIM), and cyclic Ion Mobility Spectrometry (cIMS). Example: TIMS.
propertyDescriptions.spatial_sampling_technique: The spatially targeted technique used to isolate or analyze specific regions of a sample. Techniques may include Laser-Capture Microdissection (LCM), Liquid Extraction Surface Analysis (LESA), or Nanodroplet Processing in One Pot for Trace Samples (nanoPOTS), among others. Example: nanoPOTS.
propertyDescriptions.ms_ionization_technique: The ionization technique used in imaging mass spectrometry, which refers to the method employed to probe the sample. Example: MALDI.
propertyDescriptions.ms_scan_mode: The mode of mass spectrometry (MS) scanning, which refers to the number of steps involved in the separation of fragments during the analysis. Example: MS1.
propertyDescriptions.label_name: The name or identifier of the chemical label used on this sample if labeling was applied. This is typically required for multiplexed experiments using techniques like Tandem Mass Tag (TMT). If sample was not labeled, this field may be left blank. Example: TMT126.
propertyDescriptions.lc_instrument_vendor: The company that manufactures the instrument used for liquid chromatography. If the instrument was custom-built or developed internally, enter "In-House". Example: Bruker.
propertyDescriptions.lc_instrument_model: The model number or name of the instrument used for liquid chromatography. Example: Bruker Elute LC-MS.
propertyDescriptions.lc_column_model: The model number or name of the liquid chromatography column used. If a custom self-packed, pulled tip capillary is utilized, enter "Pulled tip capillary". Example: Thermo Scientific Vanquish UHPLC.
propertyDescriptions.lc_resin: The details of the resin used in liquid chromatography, including information about the vendor, particle size, and pore size. Example: Thermo Fisher Scientific, Acclaim PepMap 100 C18, 3 µm, 100 Å.
propertyDescriptions.lc_column_length_value: The length of the liquid chromatography (LC) column used in the assay. Example: 150.
propertyDescriptions.lc_column_length_unit: The unit of measurement for the LC column length value. If the column length is not specified, this field may be left blank. Example: mm.
propertyDescriptions.lc_temperature_value: The temperature at which the liquid chromatography (LC) process is conducted. Example: 40.
propertyDescriptions.lc_temperature_unit: The unit of measurment for the LC temperature value. If the temperature is not specified, this field may be left blank. Example: celsius.
propertyDescriptions.lc_inner_diameter_value: The inner diameter of the liquid chromatography column. Example: 75.
propertyDescriptions.lc_inner_diameter_unit: The unit of measurment for the LC inner diameter value. If the diameter is not specified, this field may be left blank. Example: um.
propertyDescriptions.lc_flow_rate_value: The flow rate value used in liquid chromatography (LC) processes. Example: 300.
propertyDescriptions.lc_gradient_value: The liquid chromatography (LC) gradient used in the assay. Example: 120.
propertyDescriptions.lc_gradient_unit: The unit of measurement for the LC gradient value. If no gradient is applied, this field may be left blank. Example: minute.
propertyDescriptions.lc_mobile_phase_a: The composition of mobile phase A used in liquid chromatography (LC) procedures. It is usually water-based and helps move the sample through the column at the start of the process. Example: Water with 0.1% formic acid.
propertyDescriptions.lc_mobile_phase_b: The composition of mobile phase B used in liquid chromatography (LC) procedures. It is usually an organic solvent like acetonitrile or methanol and is gradually increased during the process to help separate different parts of the sample as they move through the column. Example: Acetonitrile with 0.1% formic acid.
propertyDescriptions.spatial_sampling_target: The cell type or functional tissue unit (FTU) that is the focus of the spatial profiling experiment. If the data are generated in imaging mode without targeting a specific structure, this field may be left blank. Example: Proximal tubule epithelial cell.
propertyDescriptions.analysis_protocol_doi: The DOI for the protocols.io page that details the software and databases used to process the raw data. Example: https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.bsu5ney6.
propertyDescriptions.data_collection_mode: The mode of data collection used in tandem MS assays, which can include options such as Data-dependent acquisition (DDA), Data-independent acquisition (DIA), multiple reaction monitoring (SRM), or parallel reaction monitoring (PRM). Example: PRM.
propertyDescriptions.lc_column_vendor: The manufacturer of the liquid chromatography column used, unless a self-packed or pulled tip capillary is employed. If the column was custom-made or developed internally, enter "In-House". Example: Bruker.
propertyDescriptions.lc_flow_rate_unit: The unit of measurement for the LC flow rate value. If the flow rate value is not specified, this field may be left blank. Example: nL/min.
propertyDescriptions.spatial_sampling_type: The type of spatial targeting used in the analysis. Spatial profiling focuses on selected tissue regions without necessarily producing images, while spatial imaging captures data across a regular grid of pixels, enabling visualization as ion intensity heat maps—also referred to as molecular images. Leave this field blank if the data originate from bulk (non-spatial) analysis. Example: Imaging.
propertyDescriptions.parent_sample_id: The unique identifier for the sample (such as a block, section, or suspension) used to perform the assay. For instance, in an RNAseq assay, the parent sample would be the suspension, while in imaging assays, it would be the tissue section. If the assay is derived from multiple parent samples, this field should contain a comma-separated list of identifiers. Identifiers may also include URLs or DOIs that point to the sample resources. Example: 10.1016/j.jchf.2022.08.010.

For instance, in an RNAseq assay, the parent sample would be the suspension, while in imaging assays, it would be the tissue section. If the assay is derived from multiple parent samples, this field should contain a comma-separated list of identifiers. Identifiers may also include URLs or DOIs that point to the sample resources. Example: 10.1016/j.jchf.2022.08.010.

about.title: about field schema
about.description: about field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 2.7.1

_ui._content:
About this metadata template

This template provides metadata fields for datasets generated by liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS), in alignment with FAIR data principles to promote data sharing and reuse. Structured metadata enhances the discoverability, accessibility, interoperability, and reproducibility of biomedical research data.

Developed through community efforts within the HuBMAP and SenNet consortia, the template leverages the CEDAR Workbench platform for streamlined metadata authoring and management. These efforts contribute to enabling broad, consistent data sharing across the research community in accordance with NIH data sharing policies.

For assistance, please visit the HuBMAP Contact page or the SenNet Contact page.

Funding: This work was supported in part by IEC-HuBMAP (NIH Award OT2OD033759), IEC-SenNet (NIH Grant U24CA268108), Penn-DCWG (NIH Grant U54HD104392), and Stanford-CEDAR (NIH Grant U54AI117925).

Citation: Use the following reference to cite the metadata specification: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41556-023-01194-w.
